newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine stocks seen fighting back.
newsitem.headline: Argentine stocks seen fighting back.

text.p: Argentine stocks were seen staging a comeback Wednesday after slumping the previous session on rumors of an immiment Brazilian devaluation, traders and analysts said.

"The market will get back into a buying mode following the other stock markets in the region. The big buyers were already taking positions at cheap prices towards the end of the trading on Tuesday," a stock analyst said.
The blue chip MerVal index tumbled 3.37 percent to 807.91 after closing off 1.7 percent Monday.
Some traders said that, Brazilian rumors aside, Tuesday's fall was a necessary correction in the Buenos Aires market, which has now lost five percent this week.

"The fears of a Brazilian devaluation were just an excuse and not a cause for the correction in share prices. There's still an expectation of a rising market," said Adolfo Adorno of Roberto Agra y Compania Sociedad de Bolsa.
He said that the easing of the Brazil fears would also help the market rebound.
Shares in oil firm YPF were seen easing, after 10 percent of its shares were sold at $29.25 each.
YPF shares closed Tuesday at 30.40 pesos. The 10 percent auctioned previously belonged to the former state-owned firm's employees.
